newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt, Lebanon say potato-apple dispute settled.
newsitem.headline: Egypt, Lebanon say potato-apple dispute settled.

text.p: Egypt and Lebanon said on Thursday they had settled a dispute over Lebanon's ban on imports of Egyptian potatoes.
Lebanon had angered Egypt by banning the imports to protect home-grown produce.
Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa said on Sunday that countermeasures might be in order, an apparent reference to Egyptian imports of Lebanese apples.

"As soon as I arrived at the airport (Egyptian Prime Minister Kamal) Ganzouri told me the issue had been settled," Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri said at a news conference with Ganzouri. "There is no economic tension."
Ganzouri said: "It is not possible that inter-Arab trade is over $300 million and we argue over $5 million or $10 million."
Hariri met Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak earlier at the start of a hastily arranged visit to Egypt.
Official sources in Egypt had said they would discuss the crisis in Arab-Israeli relations over Jerusalem and a bilateral dispute over Egyptian potato exports to Lebanon.
But Hariri laughed at the idea that he had come to discuss the potato-apple dispute.
"This is not the issue I have come for," he said. "I felt ashamed to raise the issue with President Mubarak."

Lebanese Agriculture Minister Shawki Fakhoury said Lebanon had imported 31,076 tonnes of agricultural produce from Egypt in the first three months of 1997 versus exports of only 2,439 tonnes in the same period.
